Questions: command to initialize a new Node.js project
Answers: npm init

Questions: How do you install Express.js in your project
Answers: npm install express

Questions: What function is used to start an Express server
Answers: app.listen(port, callback)

Questions: How do you send a JSON response in Express
Answers: res.json({ key: 'value' })

Questions: What is the purpose of node_modules
Answers: It contains all the installed dependency packages/libraries

Questions: How do you export a function named myFunc from a module
Answers: module.exports = myFunc; or exports.myFunc = myFunc;

Questions: How do you read a file asynchronously in Node.js
Answers: Using fs.readFile()

Questions: How do you access environment variables in Node.js
Answers: process.env.VARIABLE_NAME

Questions: What middleware parses incoming JSON payloads
Answers: express.json()

Questions: What is the purpose of the next argument in a middleware function
Answers: It passes control to the next middleware function in the stack

Questions: What HTTP status code represents "Not Found"
What HTTP status code represents "Internal Server Error"
How do you stop a running Node process in the terminal
Answers: Ctrl + C

Questions: How do you import a local file named helper.js
Answers: const helper = require('./helper');

Questions: What is the command to uninstall a package
Answers: npm uninstall package-name

Questions: What is nodemon used for
Answers: Automatically restarting the Node application when file changes are detected

Questions: How do you access the request body in Express
Answers: req.body

Questions: Is require synchronous or asynchronous
Answers: Synchronous

Questions: Which object allows you to access dynamic route parameters
Answers: req.params

Questions: How do you import the http module in Node.js
Answers: const http = require('http');

Questions: What is the difference between app.use() and app.get()
Answers: app.use() applies middleware to all requests (or a specific path prefix), whereas app.get() only matches GET requests for a specific route

Questions: How do you handle 404 errors in Express
Answers: Add a middleware function at the very end of the stack that sends a 404 response

Questions: Explain the concept of "Error Handling Middleware"
Answers: It is a function with 4 arguments: (err, req, res, next). Express recognizes this signature as an error handler

Questions: Why shouldn't you block the Event Loop
Answers: Because Node.js is single-threaded; blocking it prevents the server from handling any other incoming requests

Questions: How do you safely handle secrets (API keys) in Node
Answers: Use environment variables (via dotenv package) and never commit .env files to version control

Questions: How do you execute multiple asynchronous tasks in paralle
Answers: Using Promise.all()

Questions: What is the purpose of express.Router()
Answers: It creates modular, mountable route handlers (mini-apps) to organize routes into separate files

Questions: What is the difference between res.send() and res.json()
Answers: res.json() enforces proper JSON headers and formatting, while res.send() automatically detects content type (text/html/json) based on the data

Questions: What is a "Stream" in Node.js
Answers: An abstract interface for working with streaming data

Questions: How does Node.js handle file uploads
Answers: Typically using middleware like multer or express-fileupload to handle multipart/form-data

Questions: What is the difference between spawn and exec in the child_process module
Answers: spawn returns a stream (better for large data/long processes), while exec buffers the output and returns it all at once (better for small commands)

Questions: What is a JWT (JSON Web Token)
Answers: A stateless way to handle authentication where a signed token is sent to the client and sent back with requests to verify identity

Questions: What is the default timeout for a Node.js HTTP server
Answers: Typically 2 minutes (120,000 ms), but it is configurable

Questions: What is the "Callback Pattern"
Answers: Passing a function as an argument to handle the result (error or data) of an asynchronous operation once it completes

Questions: Why do we prefer async/await over callbacks
Answers: It avoids "Callback Hell" and makes asynchronous code look and behave more like synchronous code, improving readability

Questions: What is the difference between dependencies and peerDependencies
Answers: dependencies are required to run the app; peerDependencies expect the host project to have a specific version of a package installed (common in plugins)

Questions: How do you connect to a MongoDB database in Node
Answers: Typically using the mongoose library or the native mongodb driver

Questions: What happens if you try to res.send twice in the same reques
Answers: Express will throw an error: "Error: Can't set headers after they are sent

Questions: How do you structure a large Express application
Answers: MVC Pattern (Model-View-Controller) or separating into routes, controllers, services, and models folders

Questions: What is Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)
Answers: A browser security feature; you handle it in Express using the cors middleware to allow requests from different domains

Questions: Explain the Phases of the Node.js Event Loop
Answers: Timers -> Pending Callbacks -> Idle/Prepare -> Poll (I/O) -> Check (setImmediate) -> Close Callbacks

Questions: Node.js is single-threaded, but how does it handle file I/O operations concurrently
Answers: libuv uses a thread pool (default 4 threads) to handle "expensive" tasks like file I/O and crypto off the main thread

Questions: What is the Cluster Module
Answers: A module that allows you to create child processes (workers) that share the same server port, enabling Node to utilize multi-core systems

Questions: What are "Worker Threads"
Answers: A module (worker_threads) that enables true multi-threading for CPU-intensive JavaScript tasks (unlike Cluster, which splits processes)

Questions: How would you debug a Memory Leak in Node.js
Answers: Using Chrome DevTools "Memory" tab (Heap Snapshots), looking for detached objects or huge closures

Questions: What is Backpressure in Streams
Answers: When the data buffer fills up faster than the consumer can process it; .pipe() handles this automatically by pausing the readable stream

Questions: Difference between Horizontal Scaling and Vertical Scaling in Node
Answers: Vertical: Adding more RAM/CPU to the single server. Horizontal: Adding more server instances and using a Load Balancer

Questions: What is a Reverse Proxy (e.g., Nginx) and why use it with Node
Answers: It sits in front of Node, handling SSL termination, static files, compression, and load balancing, protecting the Node process

Questions: What is Buffer in Node.js
Answers: A global class to handle binary data (raw memory allocation) directly, necessary because JS originally only handled strings

Questions: Explain "Keep-Alive" in HTTP and how it affects Node
Answers: It keeps the TCP connection open for multiple requests, reducing handshake overhead. Node enables this by default in recent versions

Questions: Difference between fork() and spawn()
Answers: fork is a special case of spawn specifically for Node processes; it establishes an IPC (Inter-Process Communication) channel between parent and child.

Questions: How does Express handle template engines
Answers: Using app.set('view engine', 'pug') and res.render()

Questions: What is "Middleware Chaining"
Answers: The mechanism where multiple middleware functions are executed in sequence using next(

Questions: How do you gracefully shut down a Node server
Answers: Listen for SIGTERM/SIGINT signals, stop accepting new connections (server.close()), finish pending requests, close DB connections, then exit

Questions: What is the difference between TCP and UDP
Answers: TCP is reliable/ordered (HTTP, WebSockets); UDP is fast/unreliable (Video streaming, DNS). Node supports both via net and dgram modules

Questions: What is a "Zombie Process"
Answers: A child process that has completed execution but still has an entry in the process table

Questions: How does Node.js Garbage Collection work
Answers: It uses V8's "Mark-and-Sweep" algorithm. It pauses execution (Stop-the-World) to free memory, which is why optimizing memory usage is critical

Questions: What is "Event Emitter" synchronous or asynchronous
Answers: Synchronous by default. When you .emit(), all listeners are called immediately in order

Questions: What is the maximum size of a single Buffer in Nod
Answers: On 64-bit systems, it is usually 2GB

Questions: What is REPL
Answers: Read-Eval-Print Loop. The interactive shell you get when you type node in the terminal
